summary: adenovirus, coronavirus, respiratory syncytial virus, rhinovirus, human metapneumovirus, parainfluenza virus, bocavirus, and enterovirus were detected. influenza vaccination rate was 21.7% (430/1,983) during the 2011–2012 season. large-scaled study on epidemiology of respiratory viruses is important to understand the situation of individual country. a retrospective analysis of the respiratory viruses was performed in patients with respiratory illnesses in south Korea [4], [6]. a lack of information regarding large-scaled multi-center viral surveillance of adult patients with ILI (influenza-like illness) in emergency department (ED) the study population included adult patients (18 years) who visited an ED with ILI from week 40, starting Sep 25, 2011, through week 22, ending Jun 2, 2012. the study population included adult patients (18 years) who visited an ED with ILI from week 40, starting Sep 25, 2011, through week 22, ending Jun 2, 2012. 4 L 5X RV15 ACE primer mix, 10 L 2X Multiplex master mix, 3 L 8-MOP solution and 3 L of the sample’s cDNA were mixed in a tube. a PCR reaction was performed using 40 cycles at 94°C for 30 seconds, 60°C for 90 seconds, 72°C for 90 seconds, followed by extension at 72°C for 10 minutes. fish’s exact test was used to analyze categorical variables. a P value of 0.05 was considered statistically significant. the study protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board. Specimen Collection A nasopharyngeal or oropharyngeal flocked swab was obtained from each ILI patient. the flocked swab was placed in viral transport medium (BD, USA) immediately and stored at 4°C. samples were then kept at 70°C until use. PCR reaction was performed using 45 cycles at 94°C for 30 seconds, 60°C for 90 seconds, 72°C for 60 seconds, followed by extension at 72°C for 10 minutes. the median age of patients was 43 years (IQR 31–63), and 811 patients were male (40.9%). at least one chronic underlying disease was found in 356 patients (18.0%) diabetes mellitus was the most frequent comorbidity (36.8%, 131/356) in patients adult patients with ILI were viruses other than influenza viruses. at least one virus was detected in 52.1% of samples in this study. influenza viruses are most likely to be identified. ICU admission and co-infection with human metapneumovirus and RSV was strongly associated with disease severity [16], [17]. viral co-infections were related to an increased probability for hospitalization in children with respiratory infection [14]. however, the impact of detection of multiple respiratory viral infections on clinical outcome has rarely been investigated in adults. edward et al.
